docs.lead_paragraph: Six weeks after proposing a limited version of a late-term abortion ban, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has reversed course, saying today that the measure would not be put to a vote. The bill would have prohibited the procedure, called partial-birth abortions by opponents, only after 24 weeks of pregnancy, instead of at any stage. It was clearly intended mostly to appease Assembly members who generally support abortion rights. Indeed, even Mr. Silver's aides conceded that the bill's only intent was to allow Democrats from more conservative districts to return home saying that they had voted for a ban.

headline.main: Abortion Bill Is Dropped In About-Face By Silver

docs.abstract: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, six weeks after proposing limited version of late-term abortion ban, says that measure will not be put to vote because it does not have enough support in health committee (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to chip away at abortion one bill at a time, Republican leaders in Congress launched an offensive today with a bill that would frequently make it a Federal crime to take a minor across state lines for an abortion. Billed as family friendly, the Republican measure focuses attention on a politically palatable issue, parental consent, that strikes an emotional chord with many mothers and fathers.

headline.main: G.O.P. Bill to Back Parental Consent Abortion Laws

docs.abstract: Republican Congressional leaders launch offensive to chip away at abortion ith bill to make it misdemeanor to take minor across state lines to circumvent state laws requiring parental consent for abortions; Senate committee holds hearing on bill; family planning groups charge effort to create obstacle to woman's right to abortion (M)
docs.snippet: Seeking to chip away at abortion one bill at a time, Republican leaders in Congress launched an offensive today with a bill that would frequently make it a Federal crime to take a minor across state lines for an abortion.    Billed as family...

docs.lead_paragraph: AS a physician's assistant, Marcia Gaddy has delivered many babies, but the first time she went into labor, she panicked. ''I didn't know what to do,'' she said. ''I was very scared and I felt very alone, even though my husband was there to hold my hand.'' So, to make childbirth easier the second time around, last year she hired a doula, a person who is trained to work as an adjunct to doctors and midwives, giving women in labor the continuous emotional and physical support that these practitioners seldom provide. ''She helped me redirect my fear into a challenge,'' Ms. Gaddy said. ''Labor went much more quickly and was much easier.''

headline.main: Benefits of Assistant for Childbirth Go Far Beyond the Birthing Room

docs.abstract: Growing number of women are hiring service of labor doula, person who is trained to work as adjunct to doctors and midwives, giving women in labor the continuous emotional and physical support these practitioners seldom provide; research shows that childbirth does go more smoothly with a doula; labor is 25 percent shorter, need for epidaural pain relief is 60 percent less and Caesarean section rate is reduced by half; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of American women with breast cancer are losing a breast unnecessarily each year because their doctors do not follow national guidelines in treating the breast cancer, the first comprehensive study of current practices shows. About 65 percent, or 117,000, of the 180,000 breast cancers diagnosed among American women each year, are classified as early stage (1 and 2). Of these, three-fourths are eligible for breast conserving therapy, which involves removing the cancer in a surgical procedure known as a lumpectomy, followed by radiation therapy.

headline.main: Mastectomy Alternative Often Ignored, Study Says

docs.abstract: Dr Monica Morrow reports on study that found tens of thousand of American women with early breast cancer are unnecessarily undergoing mastectomy because their doctors do not follow national guidelines on using breast conserving therapy, American Society of Clinical Oncology meeting, Los Angeles; says only 44 percent of 18,000 women studied had breast sparing therapy, although more than half were eligible (M)
docs.snippet: Tens of thousands of American women with breast cancer are losing a breast unnecessarily each year because their doctors do not follow national guidelines in treating the breast cancer, the first comprehensive study of current practices shows.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: A Makeover for Laura Ashley The name Laura Ashley is enough to give hip minimalists nightmares of being smothered in lilacs or some other brutal array of florals. The label, which once made a virtue of English country style, has fallen out of favor with many customers. Now the company is trying to engineer a turnaround. A more contemporary look, designed by Kimball Stoddard, an American, reaches stores in the next couple of weeks. On Friday, Malayan United Industries, a Malaysian property and retailing company, bought a 40 percent interest in Laura Ashley.
docs.abstract: Laura Ashley apparel has fallen out of favor with many customers; Kimball Stoddard has designed more contemporary look that reaches stores in next couple of weeks (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Melinda Wagner began to compose her ''Concerto for Flute, Strings and Percussion'' she would walk away from the piano, lay the sheets of music on her bed in her Mount Vernon home and conduct through what she had so far written. ''I envisioned the orchestra,'' she said. ''I was trying to get a sense of what might come next.'' Paul Lustig Dunkel, the music director and conductor of the Westchester Philharmonic, commissioned Ms. Wagner to write the piece for the orchestra's 15th anniversary. The world premiere of the concerto will be part of a 15th-anniversary concert, titled ''Made to Order,'' on May 30 at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College. There will be a second performance on May 31.
docs.abstract: Article on composer Melinda Wagner, who has completed commissioned piece for Westchester Philharmonic's 15th anniversary; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was around the time she signed up for a radiation experiment that Carrie Specht made her decision. A graduate student at New York University's film school, she had already worked a string of menial jobs, from dog-walking to monitoring alcohol consumption at fraternity parties, and was borrowing a buck or two a day to feed herself on plain bagels and pizza specials. Now she found herself sitting in a sensory deprivation chamber, participating in a scientific inquiry into the effect of isotopes on the human memory and earning $250 for four days. ''I thought, 'There's got to be a better way,' '' Ms. Specht said. ''I mean, I have a college education.''
docs.abstract: Article on expansion of human egg donor programs at medical centers in New York City; focuses on Carrie Specht, who has had her eggs harvested four times and has been paid $9,000, money she used for New York University tuition, to finance her film projects and pay old bills; on May 14, Specht graduated with master's degree in fine arts; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: When the first inter-cadet marriage known to have taken place at West Point came to the attention of academy officials, the cadets were faced with a choice between love and military honor. The officials said the cadets chose honor. In marrying secretly off campus, the two had violated United States Military Academy rules; when faced with the probability of discipline, they got an annulment before military investigators could expel them. The cadets, who married in 1997, also had a baby, according to The Times Herald-Record of Middletown, N.Y. The academy would not confirm the birth or identify the cadets.

headline.main: May 10-16; Military Rules Meet Love. Love Retreats.

docs.lead_paragraph: As she ordered a morning latte in Boston's Faneuil Hall Marketplace today, Jane Swift made a point of making the point that it was only a decaf. ''For some people, I can't do anything right these days,'' she said, only half-joking.

headline.main: A Pregnant Candidate Discovers She's an Issue

docs.abstract: Jane Swift, who is running to be lieutenant governor of Massachusetts, is 17 weeks pregnant; that make her first expectant mother to run for statewide office in Massachusetts, and--to her outrage--focus of swirl of local debate about pregnant women in politics and the workplace; photo (M)
